comments.commentBody:
Paul, I think you're being quite unfair to women's soccer in the US. Compare the US to any other country in the world, no one has better infrastructure for the womens game with the exception of Germany and maybe Sweden. Most countries have nothing and even England will only have a semi-pro league by next year.

Yes, every team in the world would like to have a Marta, but if you've read NYT's profile on her last year (http://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/05/magazine/05marta-t.html?scp=5&sq=marta&st=cse), you'd realise that Brazil never did much to encourage her talent. It isn't Abby Wambach's fault that she was born a giant and not a soccer magician. I too prefer to watch Marta on TV than AW, but AW has contributed a lot to WNT. The woman must hold some kind of record for getting her head busted open. For that, we should be grateful.

Brazil has entertaining players, but their FA has zero funding for their womens team, no professional woman's league, and in general, not a great attitude towards the endeavor. Clearly, they did nothing to deserve the talent they ended up with. The true comparison to the US is Germany, who are heads and shoulders above the rest right now. They also play a physical, not very attractive style. But they're great at it. The creation of the WPS might have actually hurt the WNT because they don't play together year round anymore, whereas Germany still keeps their talent domestic, with less foreign players than WPS. But all is not lost, we have some great young players up front like Alex Morgan and Amy Rodriguez and we have no shortage of awesome goalies.

Best of luck to the US WNT tomorrow in Chicago. I already have tickets for the WWC next year, so hope to see you there!

I remember reading Challawa in my uncle's house in a small village in Punjab. It was being passed around from hand to hand and was quite popular. It was a complete surprise to me; I had not even known that such digests existed. And yes, they all disappeared after the CIA arrived bearing gifts in 1980....

As a former Marine, Believe me when I say, a company of tanks WILL make a difference in this area! The 3/5 Marines who are currently fighting for control of Sangin will deffinitely benefit from having these "14" tanks and the 115 Marines who support this tank unit. The 3/5 Battalion took quite a few loses in the early stages of this asignment but I know for a fact, the our Marines have learned tough lessons and they are methodically taking control of this area from the Taliban. These insurgents CAN NOT and WILL NOT match the superiorority of Our Marines. As we speak, the taliban are either dying or running from our Marines. The tanks will be another weapon that we will use to bust up the taliban mud huts and compounds.

The 3/5 Darkhorse Welcome this Tank Unit!

Semper Fi
Actually 120mm HE rounds are a great way to destroy those omnipresent hard-as-concrete mud walls. And they do less damage than an airstrike.

Tanks are like any tool - useful when used correctly. I can foresee the us using the tanks appropriately, unlike the USSR doctrine where they treated all problems as nails and the tanks as the hammer. What surprises me is that we hadn't deployed them earlier.

First of all, we cannot compare ourselves to any other country, because we are not any other country. We are the United States of America, we have our own culture and thoughts and views and just because Canada has allowed LGBT membes into their military openly doesn't mean we should do what they do. Secondly, homosexuality presents a large problem for those who are currently serving and are part of the LGBT community, there may be reprercussions against these individuals. Serving in a combat unit builds bonds beyond all imaginability and being LGBT wouldnt change that, it would just make those bonds harder to forge, In short this policy must be reviewed, however I feel it is in the best interest of our armed forces to uphold some sort of Dont Ask Dont Tell type of policy.

So what's the point?  Is there any area of human endeavor in which events of a few decades ago cannot be juxtaposed with current events to show the futility in general of the human comedy?  "Everything old is new again."  Tres trite for the august Times.

The scrabbly idea made for a good theme. I never knew LLChillJ actually stood for something, just thought it was Puff Daddy's real name. I notice that on elevators most eyes are averted, or at least akimbo, so little ogling occurs.
A Texas republican appellate court will overturn his conviction. Unfortunately.
Happy I will no longer have to endure him as a political commentator on Hardball. I found it repulsive and incomprehensible MSNBC and Chris Matthews deemed him deserving of being a guest on the show.

What's disgusting is he will probably just get probation or a 1 year sentence.  A republican judge that he had nominated to the bench threw out far more serious charges against him. I guess it's better than nothing, at least he's a convicted felon now.
He hasn't gone to jail yet. Remember this is America... the poor go to jail, the rich get pardoned.

Isn't he a law'n order guy? He should be asking for the chair, to spare taxpayers the useless sunk costs of life in prison.
Notice that he picked the judge not the jury to have the final say; he probably has a bunch of pull and favors to call in and will get an inside deal. But his attitude is like any criminal; it's not crime, it's the cop, the law, and the judge that are wrong. When a car thief does that we add 50% to their sentence.

This is no time for a weak, liberal sentence. The public needs to be protected from people such as this. No discounts, time off, country club prisons are mistress visits. 30 years actual in a real prison, general population, no special perks, might be enough for this guy to learn right from wrong.
It'll be overturned on appeal. Count on it.

He was shamelessly and openly corrupt. He was proud to be corrupt. He waved his corrption in all of our faces day in and day out - year after miserable year.

And then he was on Dancing With the Stars. How incredibly weird was that?!?!?

I just hope he does real time behind bars.

What do you call one sleazy tried and convicted Republican?

A good start.
hurray for the texas jury that ruled justice be done. now if the u.s. supreme court could have a comeuppance about it's blind eye to corporate skullduggery.
Jailing DeLay will do nothing to change the redistricting back.  That is like sending an embezzler to jail but letting him keep the money.

"The criminalization of politics undermines our very system”, claims Mr. Delay.

Rather, sir, it's your politicization of criminality that undermines our very system.

Poster # 396:  " De lay was the force behind the impeachment drive  against Bill  Clinton"  Oh, thanks, now I get "it!"    It's all about the usual  party  partisanship stuff!    Not about "justice" ....

DeLay will get a guaranteed walk on his appeal.  The convoluted logic of the charge will not hold up.  In the end, legally not guilty. Definitely sleazy.  But, if sleazy is made illegal, most politics will disappear.

This disease of corporates and wealthy individuals donating money to political parties corrupt the political systems world wide. It has a tendency of destroying a country's moral system and hampering the developmental goals of a nation. Nonetheless, I would like to ask the wisdom behind politicizing the jury in this particular case? Why did we have to have six democrats and only one republican on the jury? does this not expose the jury to prejudice? Why didn't they assign independent jurors only, people who are not affiliated to any of the political parties?. I hope that the international legal community recognize this sickness of funding political parties and develop an international law that will ban companies and wealthy individuals from funding political parties, because a lot of money is wasted on such campaigns at the expense of the have nots. When politicians receive such funds they are less likely to make decisions that are not in the interest of donors. We have seen it during the banana trade dispute between the US and Britain.

"...a political vendetta by Democrats?" DeLay asserts. “This is an abuse of power,” he said. “It’s a miscarriage of justice... the cannibalization of politics undermines our very system.

Now, take for instance the previous "8-years" of a Republican-controlled congress and West Wing-unparalleled corruption.

Tom DeLay's laments could have just as easily been ripped from Mr. Delay's likely forthcoming autobiography: "Texas: No "Delay" in Swift Justice!"

Tom Delay... as well his fellow Republican colleagues, need only to confess for the fiscal destructiveness left in their wake. And that's now eight-years and counting.

Sorry to see it happen, Tom and his wife were real big-shots in D. C. and pretty much destroyed all kinds of peoples lives by pushing through legislation, that normally would not have taken place. This case has shed light on some of those injustices. unfortunately the light sentencing he will receive for violating the public trust will pale compared to what he should get. I know Tom will seek to re-base line his conviction and re-frame this great miscarriage of justice.
I really think that he has gotten a fair trial in Texas, so how could the out come be any different on appeal other than on some technicality. Well I am sure figure that out when they get there I hope sentencing can find the right balance of punishment, probation doesn't seem right for someone who knows better and is held to a higher level of standards. This graft need to be corralled and roped in with some good ol' fashion Texas style justice and I wish hanging were still on the table. Maybe Tom can fix it all on appeal and still get to push his wife into a job at the FAA in 2012 like he tried a few years ago. What could she need to know? heck shes ridden on planes before right, and with Lockheed-Martin greasing the way, pee-u well that next big contracting opportunity is just a few years a way. yee-haw y'all thanks for all the hard work send us another real soon ya hear now.

I was going to rage about the idiocy of allowing our possessions to define us, as if this is something new. But it's not -- there were Colt and Winchester men long before Ford and Chevy and PC and Mac. Whatever. It's still pathetic to be more passionate about our things than about each other.
